title: The Three Pillars of NDC - Did We Achieve Them?
excerpt: Cost, Control, and Retail were NDC's founding goals. A decade later, how much progress have we actually made?
author: Ann Cederhall
content:
When IATA filed Resolution 787 in 2013, NDC was built on three foundational pillars: Cost, Control, and Retail. Let's examine whether we've achieved them.

Pillar 1: Cost Reduction

Airlines sought to cut astronomical GDS distribution expenses—Lufthansa cited '$1 billion dollars a year' as motivation. NDC was meant to replicate low-cost carriers' direct-to-consumer model.

Status: Mixed results. Direct PSS bookings reduce expenses for some airlines, though implementation costs complicate calculations. Travel agents may face additional expenses.

Pillar 2: Control

Airlines wanted authority over what products were sold through which channels and to whom, eliminating intermediary manipulation of fares.

Status: Minimal achievement. Airlines abandoned the concept of directly ticketing orders. The battles about control are still around with little meaningful change despite NDC implementation.

Pillar 3: Retail

The core objective—enabling airlines to sell through any channel using the same capabilities available on their own websites.

Status: Disappointing performance. Research indicates 85% of airlines are unhappy with their websites. Only 15% excel, predominantly low-cost carriers and select network airlines who invested in flexible offer-management systems and customer-centric design.

The Path Forward

Success requires flexible backend systems paired with intuitive front-end interfaces—what IATA calls ONE Order combined with strong UX. Technology alone isn't enough; you need the right architecture and a genuine focus on customer experience.
